elements.content: Six zinc metal–organic frameworks, namely, [Zn­(bpmb)­(HCOO)] n ·[Zn(bpmb)­(OH)] n ·​4nH2O (1), [Zn­(bpmb)­(HCOO)] n (2), [Zn2­(bpmb)2­(fum)] n ·​9nH2O (3), [Zn3­(bpmb)2­(d-cam)2] n (4), [Zn2­(bpmb)­(1,3,5-btc)] n ·​nDMA (5), and [Zn­(bpmb)­(1,2,4,5-H2btec)] n ·​4nH2O (6) (Hbpmb = 3,5-bis­(4-pyridyl­methoxy)­benzoic acid; H2fum = fumaric acid; d-H2cam = d-camphoric acid; 1,3,5-H3btc = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid; 1,2,4,5-H4btec = 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid; DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide), were synthesized under solvothermal conditions. Their structures were characterized by EA, IR, PXRD, TG, and single-crystal XRD. Complex 1 is constructed of two independent neutral 3D MOFs with large 1D nanosized square channels, which are further entangled by each other to give an unexpected 4-fold [2 + 2] interpenetrating architecture. Complex 2 is a 3D MOF constructed from tetradentate bpmb and bidentate formate ligands, which is an isomer of the [Zn(bpmb)­(HCOO)] n piece in 1. Complex 3 displays a 2D double-layered network that possesses 1D nanosized pores. Each 2D double layer is further interlocked with two neighboring ones to form an interesting 3D polycatenation array. Complex 4 possesses a 2D network constructed from a trinuclear [Zn3­(COO)6­N4] cluster and Zn–cam double-helical chain. Complex 5 is a 3D porous MOF constructed from tridentate bpmb and hexadentate 1,3,5-btc ligands. Complex 6 exhibits a 2-fold interpenetrating 2D wavelike (4,4) network constructed from bidentate bpmb and 1,2,4,5-H2btec ligands. The bpmb ligand adopts four types of coordination modes in 1–6. The secondary carboxylate ligands have obvious effects on their coordination architectures. Tetrahedral-, octahedral-, and trigonal-bipyramidal geometries around Zn(II) ions are observed. A general solvothermal method is proposed for preparing carboxylate complexes in DMF−H2O solution without any basic additive. In the preparation of 3, maleic acid is converted to a fumarate ligand. The thermal stabilities of six complexes and N2 adsorption behaviors of 1 and 3 are investigated. All the Zn(II) complexes emit blue luminescence originating from ligand-centered emission.

elements.content: Over the past decade, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) and coordination polymers (CPs) have attracted great interest owing to their intriguing structural and topological motifs as well as distinctive physical properties, such as luminescent, magnetic, ferroelectric, catalysis, ion exchange, porous adsorption, and biomedical imaging. Much effort has been focused on the rational design and controlled synthesis of MOFs and CPs using multidentate ligands, such as polycarboxylate and N-heterocyclic ligands. By closely controlling the properties of ligands, such as the shape, functionality, flexibility, conformation, and symmetry, metal–organic frameworks with fantastic structures and desirable properties can be created. Rigid polycarboxylate and pyridylcarboxylate ligands have been widely used in the construction of high dimensional structures with large pores. Relative to rigid ligands, flexible or semirigid polycarboxylates and pyridylcarboxylates have more advantages, because their flexibility and conformational freedom allow them to conform to the coordination environment of metal ions. Meanwhile, interpenetration as an important entanglement phenomenon is frequently observed in porous MOFs. Recently, the design and synthesis of new entangled systems, such as polycatenation MOFs, are of quite interest due to their intriguing topological structures and potential applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past decade, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and coordination polymers (CPs) have attracted great interest owing to their intriguing structural and topological motifs as well as distinctive physical properties, such as luminescent, magnetic, ferroelectric, catalysis, ion exchange, porous adsorption, and biomedical imaging. Much effort has been focused on the rational design and controlled synthesis of MOFs and CPs using multidentate ligands, such as polycarboxylate and N-heterocyclic ligands. By closely controlling the properties of ligands, such as the shape, functionality, flexibility, conformation, and symmetry, metal-organic frameworks with fantastic structures and desirable properties can be created. Rigid polycarboxylate and pyridylcarboxylate ligands have been widely used in the construction of high dimensional structures with large pores. Relative to rigid ligands, flexible or semirigid polycarboxylates and pyridylcarboxylates have more advantages, because their flexibility and conformational freedom allow them to conform to the coordination environment of metal ions. Meanwhile, interpenetration as an important entanglement phenomenon is frequently observed in porous MOFs. Recently, the design and synthesis of new entangled systems, such as polycatenation MOFs, are of quite interest due to their intriguing topological structures and potential applications.

elements.content: To continue our study on functional MOFs and CPs, we chose a flexible 3,5-bis­(4-pyridyl­methoxy)­benzoic acid (Hbpmb) as a primary ligand for our synthetic strategy. Hbpmb contains a rigid phenylcarboxyl piece and two freely rotating pyridyl arms combined by intervening methoxy groups. The cooperation of the rigid carboxylate group and flexible pyridyl arms would afford a directional control at three-dimensional extensions. This trigonal ligand may cause the planes of the pyridyl rings to rotate with respect to the plane of the central phenyl ring, and therefore, it is a good candidate to produce unique structural motifs with beautiful aesthetics. Previously, Su and co-workers have prepared and structurally characterized some 3,5-bis(4-pyridyl­methoxy)­benzoate coordination polymers. On the other hand, poly­(carboxylic acid)s, such as trimesic acid, pyromellitic acid, fumaric acid, and d-camphoric acid, have been extensively employed to construct MOFs and CPs. Considering that 3,5-bis(4-pyridyl­methoxy)­benzoate is a large-sized ligand with less negative charge (−1 valence), we use the above four polycarboxylates as secondary ligands to supply a negative charge and to promote structural diversity in constructing various MOFs.
elements.clean_text: To continue our study on functional MOFs and CPs, we chose a flexible 3,5-bis(4-pyridylmethoxy)benzoic acid (Hbpmb) as a primary ligand for our synthetic strategy. Hbpmb contains a rigid phenylcarboxyl piece and two freely rotating pyridyl arms combined by intervening methoxy groups. The cooperation of the rigid carboxylate group and flexible pyridyl arms would afford a directional control at three-dimensional extensions. This trigonal ligand may cause the planes of the pyridyl rings to rotate with respect to the plane of the central phenyl ring, and therefore, it is a good candidate to produce unique structural motifs with beautiful aesthetics. Previously, Su and co-workers have prepared and structurally characterized some 3,5-bis(4-pyridylmethoxy)benzoate coordination polymers. On the other hand, poly(carboxylic acid)s, such as trimesic acid, pyromellitic acid, fumaric acid, and d-camphoric acid, have been extensively employed to construct MOFs and CPs. Considering that 3,5-bis(4-pyridylmethoxy)benzoate is a large-sized ligand with less negative charge (-1 valence), we use the above four polycarboxylates as secondary ligands to supply a negative charge and to promote structural diversity in constructing various MOFs.

elements.content: In the preparation reactions of polycarboxylate complexes, the pH value of the entire solution system has an important impact on the final products. It is well-known that metal–hydroxide precipitates are easily produced when preparing carboxylate complexes using NaOH or triethylamine as base. Recently, we notice that the deprotonated process of carboxyl acid can be conveniently completed by solvothermal reaction in DMF (dimethylformamide) and water mixed solvent without any basic additive. Under such near neutral reaction conditions, metal–hydroxide precipitates could be avoided. In this work, we prepare the polycarboxylate complexes by solvothermal reaction in DMF or DMA (N,N-dimethylacetamide) water mixed solvent. Moreover, we select Zn(II) as a central ion, not only for the reason that Zn(II) is easily coordinated by N- and O-containing ligands but also for that the closed-shell d10 metal ions can give rise to interesting luminescent behaviors. To date, four Zn(II) complexes containing 5-bis(4-pyridyl­methoxy)­benzoate ligand were reported. These are [Zn­(bpmb)2] n ·​nH2O (1D), [Zn­(bpmb)­(bpdc)0.5] n (2D), [Zn(bpmb)­(OAc)] n ·​nH2O (2D), and [Zn(bpmb)­(bdc)0.5] n (3D). By using 3,5-bis(4-pyridyl­methoxy)­benzoate as the primary ligand and four polycarboxylates as secondary ligands (Scheme ), we have successfully prepared six porous Zn(II) MOFs with an unexpected 4-fold [2 + 2] interpenetration and polycatenation behaviors. Herein, we report their synthesis, crystal structures, thermal stabilities, N2 adsorption, and luminescence.

Moreover, we select Zn(II) as a central ion, not only for the reason that Zn(II) is easily coordinated by N- and O-containing ligands but also for that the closed-shell d10 metal ions can give rise to interesting luminescent behaviors. These are [Zn(bpmb)2] n ⋅nH2O (1D), [Zn(bpmb)(bpdc)0.5] n  (2D), [Zn(bpmb)(OAc)] n ⋅nH2O (2D), and [Zn(bpmb)(bdc)0.5] n  (3D). elements.content: All chemicals were of reagent grade and used as received without further purification. C, H, and N analyses were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded with a Nicolet A370 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the 400–4000 cm–1 range. Powder X-ray diffractions were measured at a scanning rate of 5° min–1 on a Rigaku DLMAX-2550 diffractometer using Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Thermogravimetric analyses were completed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 in air. Nitrogen (N2) sorption experiments were carried out on a Micromeritics ASAP2020 M surface area analyzer. The samples were activated by using the “outgas” function of the surface area analyzer for 7 h at 120 °C. Luminescent spectra were recorded using solid samples on a Shimadzu RF-5301 spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals were of reagent grade and used as received without further purification. C, H, and N analyses were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded with a Nicolet A370 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the 400-4000 cm-1 range. Powder X-ray diffractions were measured at a scanning rate of 5° min-1 on a Rigaku DLMAX-2550 diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Thermogravimetric analyses were completed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 in air. Nitrogen (N2) sorption experiments were carried out on a Micromeritics ASAP2020 M surface area analyzer. The samples were activated by using the "outgas" function of the surface area analyzer for 7 h at 120 °C. Luminescent spectra were recorded using solid samples on a Shimadzu RF-5301 spectrophotometer.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·​​6H2O (0.2 mmol), Hbpmb (0.05 mmoL), DMF (3 mL), and H2O (3 mL) was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined reactor. The reactor was heated at 85 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C h–1. Colorless rhombic crystals of 1 were obtained in 80% yield based on Hbpmb. Anal. Calcd for C39H40­N4O15Zn2: C, 50.06; H, 4.30; N, 5.99. Found: C, 48.89; H, 4.15; N, 6.15. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3405m, 3099w, 2929w, 2848w, 1625s, 1585s, 1431m, 1372s, 1174s, 1063s, 786s, 490m.

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of 1–6 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex-II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296(2) K except for 3 at 193(2) K. Determinations of the crystal system, orientation matrix, and cell dimensions were performed according to the established procedures. Lorentz polarization and absorption correction were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares techniques with the SHELXTL program. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were placed geometrically and refined using the riding model. The missing water molecules in 1 that were decided by element analysis and TGA were also added into the final formula. DMA in 5 is highly disordered. The crystallographic data and structural refinement results are summarized in Table . The selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of 1-6 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex-II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296(2) K except for 3 at 193(2) K. Determinations of the crystal system, orientation matrix, and cell dimensions were performed according to the established procedures. Lorentz polarization and absorption correction were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares techniques with the SHELXTL program. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were placed geometrically and refined using the riding model. The missing water molecules in 1 that were decided by element analysis and TGA were also added into the final formula. DMA in 5 is highly disordered. The crystallographic data and structural refinement results are summarized in Table . The selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table .

In order to check the phase purity of the products, powder X-ray diffraction experiments have been carried out for 1–6 (Figure S1a–f, ). The peak positions of the measured and simulated PXRD patterns are in good agreement with each other, indicating that the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk crystal products. The differences in intensity may be owing to the preferred orientation of the crystal samples.

elements.content: The colorless crystal complexes 1–6 were synthesized by the solvothermal reactions of Zn­(NO3)2·​6H2O with the 3,5-bis(4-pyridyl­methoxy)­benzoic acid primary ligand and/or various poly(carboxylic acid) secondary ligands in DMF/DMA–H2O mixed solvent, except for complex 6 prepared in MeCN–H2O solution. The molar ratio of Zn­(NO3)2·​6H2O and Hbpmb was kept in 4:1 in these preparation reactions, except for complex 2 prepared in a molar ratio of 2:1. The molar ratio of Hbpmb and poly­(carboxylic acid)s was changed from 1:1 for 4 and 5 to 1:2 for 3 and 6. After the above solvothermal reactions, the pH values of the reaction mixtures were checked, which were 6.0 (1), 6.0 (2), 5.5 (3), 5.5 (4), 5.5 (5), and 5.5 (6). In the preparation reactions of 3–6, various poly­(carboxylic acid)s as secondary ligands are added. Their pH 5.5 is lower than the pH 6.0 in the reaction mixtures of 1 and 2 where only the 3,5-bis(4-pyridyl­methoxy)­benzoic acid primary ligand is added. In such pH conditions, carboxyl groups are easily deprotonated and coordinate to metal ions, while the metal–hydroxide precipitate could be avoided.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and Infrared Spectra

The colorless crystal complexes 1-6 were synthesized by the solvothermal reactions of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O with the 3,5-bis(4-pyridylmethoxy)benzoic acid primary ligand and/or various poly(carboxylic acid) secondary ligands in DMF/DMA-H2O mixed solvent, except for complex 6 prepared in MeCN-H2O solution. The molar ratio of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O and Hbpmb was kept in 4:1 in these preparation reactions, except for complex 2 prepared in a molar ratio of 2:1. The molar ratio of Hbpmb and poly(carboxylic acid)s was changed from 1:1 for 4 and 5 to 1:2 for 3 and 6. After the above solvothermal reactions, the pH values of the reaction mixtures were checked, which were 6.0 (1), 6.0 (2), 5.5 (3), 5.5 (4), 5.5 (5), and 5.5 (6). In the preparation reactions of 3-6, various poly(carboxylic acid)s as secondary ligands are added. Their pH 5.5 is lower than the pH 6.0 in the reaction mixtures of 1 and 2 where only the 3,5-bis(4-pyridylmethoxy)benzoic acid primary ligand is added. In such pH conditions, carboxyl groups are easily deprotonated and coordinate to metal ions, while the metal-hydroxide precipitate could be avoided.

elements.content: In this work, the deprotonated processes of carboxyl groups were conveniently completed by the solvothermal reactions in DMF/DMA–H2O mixed solvent without any basic additive. We consider that the hydrolysis of DMF/DMA at solvothermal conditions could generate basic compound Me2NH (Scheme ), which promotes the deprotonation procedure of the carboxyl group in Hbpmb and poly(carboxylic acid)s. The formate ligand observed in 1 indicates the hydrolysis procedure of DMF. Recently, Liu et al. reported a complex [Mn6­(HEBDC)4­(H2O)8]·​3Me2NH·​2DMF·​H2O prepared in DMF solution at 105 °C. Obviously, Me2NH is produced by the hydrolysis of DMF. Similar DMF hydrolysis behavior was also observed in complex (Me2NH)2­[Cu9­(bshz)3­(Py)10­(C2H7N)­(DMF)]·2DMF. This is why some carboxylate complexes can be prepared solvothermally in DMF solution without any basic additive recently. It is well-known that metal–hydroxide precipitates are easily produced when preparing carboxylate complexes using NaOH or triethylamine as base. Now, we can prepare carboxylate complexes conveniently using solvothermal reactions in DMF/DMA solution without a basic additive.

We consider that the hydrolysis of DMF/DMA at solvothermal conditions could generate basic compound Me2NH (Scheme ), which promotes the deprotonation procedure of the carboxyl group in Hbpmb and poly(carboxylic acid)s. The formate ligand observed in 1 indicates the hydrolysis procedure of DMF. Recently, Liu et al. reported a complex [Mn6(HEBDC)4(H2O)8]⋅3Me2NH⋅2DMF⋅H2O prepared in DMF solution at 105 °C. Obviously, Me2NH is produced by the hydrolysis of DMF. Similar DMF hydrolysis behavior was also observed in complex (Me2NH)2[Cu9(bshz)3(Py)10(C2H7N)(DMF)]⋅2DMF. This is why some carboxylate complexes can be prepared solvothermally in DMF solution without any basic additive recently. It is well-known that metal-hydroxide precipitates are easily produced when preparing carboxylate complexes using NaOH or triethylamine as base. Now, we can prepare carboxylate complexes conveniently using solvothermal reactions in DMF/DMA solution without a basic additive.

elements.content: It is noteworthy that cis–trans isomerization was observed in the preparation reaction of 3, in which maleic acid is converted to fumarate ligand (Scheme ). The trans-fumaric acid is more stable than the cis-maleic acid. This in situ conformation conversion was frequently observed in previous reports. For example, a similar in situ isomerization of maleic acid to fumarate occurred during the hydrothermal preparation of [Zn­(2-pytpy)­(fum)] n ·​nH2O and in the ambient temperature synthesis of [Zn(fum)­(bpmp)­(H2O)2] n .

elements.content: The infrared spectra of 1–6 (Figure S2a–f, ) exhibit characteristic bands of 3,5-bis(4-pyridylmethoxy)benzoate. The bands near 3080, 2920, 1174, and 770 cm–1 are, respectively, assigned to the ν(Ar–H), ν(−CH2), ν(C–O), and γ(Ar–H) vibrations of bpmb. The characteristic strong absorption bands of the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylate groups appear at about 1585 and 1372 cm–1, respectively. Complex 6 displays two νas(COOH) characteristic absorption peaks at 1725 and 1684 cm–1, which indicates that two carboxyl groups of 1,2,4,5-H2btec maintain protonation. In addition, the characteristic ν(−CH3) stretching vibration of camphorate occurs at 2969 cm–1. These IR spectra are in good agreement with the results of elemental analysis and X-ray structural analysis.

In addition, the characteristic ν(-CH3) stretching vibration of camphorate occurs at 2969 cm-1. These IR spectra are in good agreement with the results of elemental analysis and X-ray structural analysis.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 is an interesting 3D metal–organic framework that consists of two independent neutral 3D porous MOFs, [Zn(bpmb)­(HCOO)] n and [Zn(bpmb)­(OH)] n . For the [Zn(bpmb)­(OH)] n piece, the asymmetric unit contains half Zn1, half Zn3, one bpmb ligand, and one hydroxyl ligand (Figure a). Zn1 is hexacoordinated by two chelating carboxyl groups and two pyridyl nitrogens to form a distorted cis-octahedral geometry. The equatorial plane is formed by the coordination of O1, O2, N3C, and O1A atoms. The axial positions are occupied by N3B and O2A atoms with a N3B–Zn1–O2A bond angle of 158.9(1)°. The Zn1–O1, Zn1–O2, and Zn1–N3B bond distances are 2.046(3), 2.362(3), and 2.104(4) Å, respectively. Zn3 adopts a distorted tetrahedral geometry, coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogens and two hydroxyl oxygens. The Zn3–N4 and Zn3–O11 bond distances are 2.031(5) and 2.191(10) Å, respectively. The bpmb ligand is tetradentate and coordinates to three Zn(II) ions via two pyridyl arms and one chelating carboxyl group (mode I, Scheme ). One pyridyl group is almost coplanar with the central phenyl ring, while the other one (containing N3) has a dihedral angle of 35.39(2)° with the phenyl ring. Zn1 and Zn3 are connected by bpmb to form a 3D MOF that shows large 1D nanosized square channels viewed along the c axis (Figure b, 13.39 × 13.39 Å2) and hexagonal channels viewed along the b axis (Figure c, 13.50 × 20.64 Å2). A pair of identical 3D [Zn(bpmb)­(OH)] n nets are interlocked to each other, thus leading to the formation of a 2-fold interpenetrated 3D framework (Figure d). From the viewpoint of network topology, each Zn1 center can be treated as a 4-connected node, and the bpmb ligand can act as a 3-connected node. Zn3 is a linear linker in the topology. Thus, the whole 3D [Zn(bpmb)­(OH)] n net can be simplified as a 2-nodal (3,4)-connected topology with the Schläfli notation of {83}2{86} (Figure S3a, ).
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures

Structure of [Zn(bpmb)(HCOO)] n ⋅[Zn(bpmb)(OH)] n ⋅4nH2O (1)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 is an interesting 3D metal-organic framework that consists of two independent neutral 3D porous MOFs, [Zn(bpmb)(HCOO)] n  and [Zn(bpmb)(OH)] n . For the [Zn(bpmb)(OH)] n  piece, the asymmetric unit contains half Zn1, half Zn3, one bpmb ligand, and one hydroxyl ligand (Figure a). Zn1 is hexacoordinated by two chelating carboxyl groups and two pyridyl nitrogens to form a distorted cis-octahedral geometry. The equatorial plane is formed by the coordination of O1, O2, N3C, and O1A atoms. The axial positions are occupied by N3B and O2A atoms with a N3B-Zn1-O2A bond angle of 158.9(1)°. The Zn1-O1, Zn1-O2, and Zn1-N3B bond distances are 2.046(3), 2.362(3), and 2.104(4) Å, respectively. Zn3 adopts a distorted tetrahedral geometry, coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogens and two hydroxyl oxygens. The Zn3-N4 and Zn3-O11 bond distances are 2.031(5) and 2.191(10) Å, respectively. The bpmb ligand is tetradentate and coordinates to three Zn(II) ions via two pyridyl arms and one chelating carboxyl group (mode I, Scheme ). One pyridyl group is almost coplanar with the central phenyl ring, while the other one (containing N3) has a dihedral angle of 35.39(2)° with the phenyl ring. Zn1 and Zn3 are connected by bpmb to form a 3D MOF that shows large 1D nanosized square channels viewed along the c axis (Figure b, 13.39 × 13.39 Å2) and hexagonal channels viewed along the b axis (Figure c, 13.50 × 20.64 Å2). A pair of identical 3D [Zn(bpmb)(OH)] n  nets are interlocked to each other, thus leading to the formation of a 2-fold interpenetrated 3D framework (Figure d). From the viewpoint of network topology, each Zn1 center can be treated as a 4-connected node, and the bpmb ligand can act as a 3-connected node. Zn3 is a linear linker in the topology. Thus, the whole 3D [Zn(bpmb)(OH)] n  net can be simplified as a 2-nodal (3,4)-connected topology with the Schläfli notation of {83}2{86} (Figure S3a, ).

elements.content: For the [Zn(bpmb)­(HCOO)] n piece, the asymmetric unit contains one Zn2, one bpmb ligand, and one formate ligand. Zn2 is in a distorted tetrahedral geometry, coordinated by two monodentate carboxyl groups and two pyridyl groups. The average Zn2–O and Zn2–N bond distances are 1.963 and 2.040 Å, respectively. The formate anion generated from the hydrolysis of DMF acts as a monodentate ligand. The bpmb ligand is tridentate and coordinates to three Zn(II) ions via two pyridyl groups and a monodentate carboxyl group (mode II, Scheme ). Both pyridyl rings are almost coplanar to the central phenyl ring with a small dihedral angle of 18.05(2)°. Zn2 ions are linked by bpmb to form a 3D MOF with large 1D nanosized square channels viewed along the c axis (Figure e, 13.39 × 13.39 Å2) and hexagonal channels viewed along the b axis (Figure f, 12.54 × 13.50 Å2). Two such 3D single nets are interlocked with each other to generate a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D framework (Figure g). Zn2 and bpmb can be treated as 3-connected nodes. Thus, the 3D [Zn(bpmb)­(HCOO)] n net can be simplified as a 3-connected topology with the Schläfli notation of {103} (Figure S3b, ). Previously, Su et al. reported a 2D {[Zn(bpmb)­(OAc)]·​​H2O} n coordination polymer, which is obviously different with our 3D [Zn(bpmb)­(HCOO)] n piece.
elements.clean_text: For the [Zn(bpmb)(HCOO)] n  piece, the asymmetric unit contains one Zn2, one bpmb ligand, and one formate ligand. Zn2 is in a distorted tetrahedral geometry, coordinated by two monodentate carboxyl groups and two pyridyl groups. The average Zn2-O and Zn2-N bond distances are 1.963 and 2.040 Å, respectively. The formate anion generated from the hydrolysis of DMF acts as a monodentate ligand. The bpmb ligand is tridentate and coordinates to three Zn(II) ions via two pyridyl groups and a monodentate carboxyl group (mode II, Scheme ). Both pyridyl rings are almost coplanar to the central phenyl ring with a small dihedral angle of 18.05(2)°. Zn2 ions are linked by bpmb to form a 3D MOF with large 1D nanosized square channels viewed along the c axis (Figure e, 13.39 × 13.39 Å2) and hexagonal channels viewed along the b axis (Figure f, 12.54 × 13.50 Å2). Two such 3D single nets are interlocked with each other to generate a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D framework (Figure g). Zn2 and bpmb can be treated as 3-connected nodes. Thus, the 3D [Zn(bpmb)(HCOO)] n  net can be simplified as a 3-connected topology with the Schläfli notation of {103} (Figure S3b, ). Previously, Su et al. reported a 2D {[Zn(bpmb)(OAc)]⋅H2O} n  coordination polymer, which is obviously different with our 3D [Zn(bpmb)(HCOO)] n  piece.

elements.content: Comparing the structures of [Zn(bmpb)­(HCOO)] n and [Zn(bmpb)­(OH)] n pieces, both neutral 3D MOFs exhibit similar square channels viewed along the c axis. Each side of the square channel is formed by a vertical bpmb plane. However, viewed along the b axis, the hexagonal channels in both 3D MOFs are obviously different. The [Zn(bpmb)­(OH)] n piece shows a hexagonal channel with the dimensions of 13.50 × 20.64 Å2. Each large hexagonal channel is followed by a small rectangle channel. The [Zn(bmpb)­(HCOO)] n piece displays a single hexagonal channel with smaller dimensions of 12.54 × 13.50 Å2. Generally, larger flexible ligands are good candidates for the assembly of versatile entangled structures, due to their propensity to form large pores and interpenetration. The most striking feature of complex 1 is that the two neutral 2-fold interpenetrated 3D porous MOFs, [Zn(bmpb)­(HCOO)] n and [Zn(bmpb)­(OH)] n , further interpenetrate to each other. This results in the formation of an unexpected 4-fold [2 + 2] interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure h). To our best knowledge, complex 1 is the first example of a metal–organic framework containing two independent neutral 3D MOFs with 4-fold [2 + 2] interpenetration. Despite that the interpenetration is 4-fold, there exists enough void space occupied by guest water molecules. The potential solvent-accessible occupancy volume is 22% calculated by the PLATON program.
elements.clean_text: Comparing the structures of [Zn(bmpb)(HCOO)] n  and [Zn(bmpb)(OH)] n  pieces, both neutral 3D MOFs exhibit similar square channels viewed along the c axis. Each side of the square channel is formed by a vertical bpmb plane. However, viewed along the b axis, the hexagonal channels in both 3D MOFs are obviously different. The [Zn(bpmb)(OH)] n  piece shows a hexagonal channel with the dimensions of 13.50 × 20.64 Å2. Each large hexagonal channel is followed by a small rectangle channel. The [Zn(bmpb)(HCOO)] n  piece displays a single hexagonal channel with smaller dimensions of 12.54 × 13.50 Å2. Generally, larger flexible ligands are good candidates for the assembly of versatile entangled structures, due to their propensity to form large pores and interpenetration. The most striking feature of complex 1 is that the two neutral 2-fold interpenetrated 3D porous MOFs, [Zn(bmpb)(HCOO)] n  and [Zn(bmpb)(OH)] n , further interpenetrate to each other. This results in the formation of an unexpected 4-fold [2 + 2] interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure h). To our best knowledge, complex 1 is the first example of a metal-organic framework containing two independent neutral 3D MOFs with 4-fold [2 + 2] interpenetration. Despite that the interpenetration is 4-fold, there exists enough void space occupied by guest water molecules. The potential solvent-accessible occupancy volume is 22% calculated by the PLATON program.

elements.content: Considering that complex 1 contains two independent neutral 3D porous MOFs, we try to prepare both individual MOFs by changing the reaction conditions. When the molar ratio of Zn­(NO3)2·​6H2O with Hbpmb was reduced to 2:1 from 4:1, complex 2 was successfully synthesized, which is an isomer of the [Zn(bpmb)­(HCOO)] n piece in 1.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of [Zn(bpmb)(HCOO)] n  (2)

Considering that complex 1 contains two independent neutral 3D porous MOFs, we try to prepare both individual MOFs by changing the reaction conditions. When the molar ratio of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O with Hbpmb was reduced to 2:1 from 4:1, complex 2 was successfully synthesized, which is an isomer of the [Zn(bpmb)(HCOO)] n  piece in 1.

elements.content: Complex 2 is a 3D MOF constructed from μ4-bpmb and μ2-HCOO– ligands. The asymmetric unit consists of one independent Zn(II) ion, one bpmb ligand, and one formate ligand (Figure a). Unlike the tetrahedral coordination of Zn2 in 1, here, Zn(II) is hexacoordinated by one chelating carboxyl group from bpmb, two formate oxygens, and two pyridyl nitrogens to complete a distorted cis-octahedral geometry. The equatorial plane is formed by the coordination of O1, O2, N1, and N2 atoms. The axial positions are occupied by O3 and O4 atoms with a O3–Zn1–O4 bond angle of 175.0(1)°. The Zn–O bond distances vary from 2.078(3) to 2.236(4) Å. The average Zn–N bond distance is 2.109 Å.

elements.content: The bpmb ligand is tetradentate and coordinates to three Zn(II) ions via two pyridyl groups and one chelating carboxyl group (mode I, Scheme ). Zn(II) ions are connected by bpmb to form a wavelike 2D [Zn-bpmb] n network (Figure b). The formate ligand adopts a bidentate bridging mode and linearly links the 2D [Zn-bpmb] n networks into a 3D porous MOF (Figure c). Viewed along the c axis, a pair of identical 3D nets are further interlocked to each other, leading to the formation of a 2-fold interpenetrated 3D framework (Figure d). Each Zn(II) center can be treated as a 5-connected node, and bpmb can be regarded as a 3-connected node. HCOO– is considered as a linear linker. Thus, the whole 3D framework can be simplified as a 2-nodal (3,5)-connected topology with the Schläfli notation of {63}­{69;8} (Figure S3c, ).

elements.content: Although complex 2 has a similar molecular formula with the [Zn(bpmb)­(HCOO)] n piece in 1, their structures are obviously different. The former shows an octahedral coordination geometry around the Zn(II) center, whereas the latter displays a tetrahedral geometry. Formate is a bidentate bridging ligand in 2, but it is a monodentate ligand in 1. Moreover, bpmb is tetradentate in 2, but tridentate in 1. Their topologic structures are obviously different.

elements.content: Complex 3 is a 2D double-layered network constructed from μ3-bpmb and μ2-fumarate ligands. Fumarate is produced from maleic acid by in situ isomerization under solvothermal conditions. The asymmetric unit contains two independent Zn(II) ions, two bpmb ligands, one fumarate ligand, and nine lattice water molecules (Figure a). Two distinct Zn(II) ions both adopt a distorted tetrahedral geometry, coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogens, one carboxyl oxygen from bpmb, and one fumarate oxygen. The bond distances and bond angles around Zn1 are somewhat different with those around Zn2 (Table ). The average Zn–O and Zn–N bond distances are 1.961 and 2.014 Å, respectively. The bond angles surrounding Zn1 and Zn2 vary from 95.8(2)° to 129.7(2)°.

elements.content: The fumarate dianion acts as a μ2-bridge to link Zn1 and Zn2 via two monodentate carboxyl groups (Scheme ). One bpmb ligand adopts a μ3-η1,η1,η1 tridentate coordination mode (mode II, Scheme ) to connect Zn1 ions to form a 2D honeycomb layer (Figure b). Similarly, another tridentate bpmb ligand links Zn2 ions to form a second 2D honeycomb layer. Both honeycomb layers are further connected by a fumarate spacer to form a 2D double-layered network (Figure c), which exhibits large 1D nanosized pores with the dimensions of 11.75 × 12.65 Å2.

elements.content: Interestingly, each 2D double-layered network is interlocked with two neighboring ones. All of the porous double-layered networks are interlocked to each other. This results in the formation of an infinite 3D polycatenation array (Figure d). From the viewpoint of network topology, the bpmb ligand can be considered as a three-connected node. Fumarate can be regarded as a two-connected node. Zn1 and Zn2 ions can be treated as four-connected nodes. Thus, the whole structure of 3 can be simplified as a 2-nodal (3,4)-connected topology with the Schläfli notation of {63}­{66} as shown in Figure e. The complex 3 contains nine lattice water molecules in each asymmetric unit. These water clusters are perched in the 1D nanopores. After the removal of the lattice water molecules, the void volume calculated by PLATON is 22%.

elements.content: Complex 4 is a 2D coordination network constructed from a trinuclear [Zn3­(COO)6­N4] cluster and a Zn–cam double helical chain. The asymmetric unit contains one Zn1 and half Zn2, one bpmb, and one d-cam. Zn1 adopts a distorted cis-octahedral geometry, coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogens and four carboxyl oxygens (Figure a). The equatorial plane is completed by the coordination of N2, O2, O1B, and O6 atoms. The axial positions are occupied by N1 and O4 atoms with a N1–Zn1–O4 bond angle of 171.2(2)°. The Zn1–O bond distances vary from 1.966(5) to 2.258(5) Å, and the average Zn1–N bond distance is 2.174 Å. Zn2 is hexacoordinated by four carboxyl oxygens from four different d-cam ligands and two carboxyl oxygens from different bpmb ligands, forming a typical octahedral geometry with an inversion center located at Zn2. The equatorial plane is completed by the coordination of O1, O1A, O3, and O3A atoms. The axial positions are occupied by O5 and O5A atoms. The O1–Zn2–O1A, O3–Zn2–O3A, and O5–Zn2–O5A bond angles are 180°. The bond distances of Zn2–O1, Zn2–O3, and Zn2–O5 are 2.205(5), 1.973(5), and 2.354(7) Å, respectively.

elements.content: The d-camphorate dianion acts as a tetradentate ligand to bridge two pairs of Zn1 and Zn2 ions via two bidentate-bridging carboxyl groups (Scheme ). Bpmb adopts a pentadentate coordination mode to connect four Zn(II) ions via two pyridyl groups and a tridentate carboxyl group (mode III, Scheme ). The tridentate carboxyl group displays a chelating-bridging fashion that chelates to Zn1 and bridges to Zn1 and Zn2 via the O1 atom (Figure b). Four carboxyl groups from four d-cam ligands and two tridentate carboxyl groups from bpmb ligands bridge Zn2 and two Zn1 ions to form a [Zn3­(COO)6­N4] trinuclear cluster with an inversion center located at the Zn2 position.

elements.content: d-Camphorate is a chiral ligand. Complex 4 contains Zn–cam double helical chains (Figure c). The left–handed (blue) and right–handed (red) helical chains are entangled to each other along the b axis, which results in the formation of a meso double-helical chain with the pitch of 9.144 Å between Zn(II) ions. Therefore, complex 4 is an achiral complex and crystallizes in an achiral P1̅ space group. Around the 1D double-helical chain, each bpmb ligand links two adjacent [Zn3­(COO)6­N4] clusters via tridentate carboxyl group and one pyridyl arm. Such 1D chains are further connected by another pyridyl arm of bpmb to form a 2D polymeric network, as shown in Figure d.

elements.content: Complex 5 is a 3D MOF constructed from μ3-bpmb and μ6-1,3,5-btc ligands. The asymmetric unit contains two independent Zn(II) ions, one bpmb, one 1,3,5-btc, and a lattice DMA molecule (Figure a). Zn1 is five-coordinated by four carboxyl oxygens from four 1,3,5-btc ligands and one pyridyl nitrogen, forming a slightly distorted trigonal-bipyramidal geometry with a τ value of 0.9801. The trigonal plane is formed by the coordination of O3, O7, and O8 atoms. The apical positions are occupied by N2 and O6 atoms with a O6–Zn1–N2 bond angle of 176.29(9)°. The Zn1–O bond distances vary from 1.986(2) to 2.172(2) Å. The Zn1–N2 bond distance is 2.123(3) Å. Zn2 displays a distorted tetrahedral geometry, coordinated by carboxyl O2 of bpmb, two carboxyl oxygens from different 1,3,5-btc, and one pyridyl nitrogen. The Zn2–O bond distances vary from 1.929(2) to 1.974(2) Å, and the Zn2–N1 distance is 2.041(2) Å.

elements.content: 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid is fully deprotonated. The 1,3,5-btc ligand adopts a μ6-η1,η1,η1,η1,η1,η1 hexadentate coordination mode (Scheme ), and each carboxyl group bridges two Zn(II) ions. As shown in Figure b, four carboxyl oxygens of 1,3,5-btc link Zn1 and Zn2 into a 2D grid layer. The other two carboxyl oxygens (O6, O8) of 1,3,5-btc connect Zn1 ions in an adjacent layer to form a 2D [Zn2­(1,3,5-btc)] n double-layered network (Figure c). Bpmb adopts a μ3-η1,η1,η1 tridentate mode to combine three Zn(II) ions via two pyridyl groups and a monodentate carboxyl group (mode II, Scheme ), which further connects [Zn2­(1,3,5-btc)] n double layers into a 3D porous MOF (Figure d). The lattice DMA molecule is perched in the pore. After the removal of the DMA molecule, the void volume calculated by PLATON is 22.1%.

elements.content: Complex 6 is a 2D wavelike porous coordination network. The asymmetric unit consists of one independent Zn(II) ion, one bpmb, one 1,2,4,5-H2btec, and four lattice water molecules (Figure a). Zn1 adopts a distorted tetrahedral geometry, coordinated by one pyridyl nitrogen and three carboxyl oxygens. Two of them are from two 1,2,4,5-H2btec ligands, and the third is from bpmb. The Zn–O bond distances vary from 1.969(2) to 1.991(2) Å, and the Zn–N1 distance is 2.043(2) Å. The O1–Zn1–O7 bond angle of 146.06(8)° is larger. Other bond angles fall in the normal range from 94.55(9)° to 104.35(8)°.

elements.content: 1,2,4,5-Benzenetetracarboxylic acid is partly deprotonated. The 1,2,4,5-H2btec dianion adopts a μ2-η1,η1 bidentate mode (Scheme ), and bridges two Zn(II) ions via two opposite monodentate carboxyl groups to form a 1D polymeric chain. Bpmb adopts a bidentate mode (mode IV, Scheme ) to link two Zn(II) ions via a monodentate carboxyl group and one pyridyl arm, which results in another 1D chain. Both 1D chains are almost orthogonal to each other, via sharing Zn(II) ions to form a 2D wavelike (4,4) network (Figure b). Two such 2D networks further interpenetrate to each other to give rise to a 2D interpenetration network (Figure c). The whole framework can be simplified as a 4-connected sql topology with the Schläfli notation of {44;62}, as shown in Figure d.

elements.content: As illustrated in Scheme , 3,5-bis(4-pyridyl­methoxy)­benzoate exhibits four types of coordination modes in six zinc complexes. Complexes 2, 4, 5, and 6 contain one independent bpmb ligand, which adopts coordination modes I, III, II, and IV, respectively. In complex 3, two independent bpmb ligands both adopt coordination mode II. In complex 1, two distinct bpmb ligands display tetradentate mode I and tridentate mode II. Both pyridyl terminals coordinate in modes I–III; however, one pyridyl terminal is free in mode IV. Complexes 1, 2, and 5 are 3D porous MOFs. Complex 3 displays a 2D double-layered network that possesses 1D nanosized pores. Complexes 4 and 6 are 2D coordination networks with voids in the parallel stacking supramolecular systems, which are also considered being MOFs according to a recent definition recommended by IUPAC.
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of Coordination Modes and Structural Diversity

As illustrated in Scheme , 3,5-bis(4-pyridylmethoxy)benzoate exhibits four types of coordination modes in six zinc complexes. Complexes 2, 4, 5, and 6 contain one independent bpmb ligand, which adopts coordination modes I, III, II, and IV, respectively. In complex 3, two independent bpmb ligands both adopt coordination mode II. In complex 1, two distinct bpmb ligands display tetradentate mode I and tridentate mode II. Both pyridyl terminals coordinate in modes I-III; however, one pyridyl terminal is free in mode IV. Complexes 1, 2, and 5 are 3D porous MOFs. Complex 3 displays a 2D double-layered network that possesses 1D nanosized pores. Complexes 4 and 6 are 2D coordination networks with voids in the parallel stacking supramolecular systems, which are also considered being MOFs according to a recent definition recommended by IUPAC.

elements.content: As secondary ligands, the poly­(carboxylic acid)s are fully deprotonated except for a partly deprotonated 1,2,4,5-H2btec ligand in 6 (Scheme ). The fumarate and 1,2,4,5-H2btec dianions both act as a bidentate bridge to link Zn(II) ions via two monodentate carboxyl groups. d-Camphorate is a tetradentate ligand to bridge two pairs of Zn(II) ions via two bidentate bridging carboxyl groups. 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylate is a hexadentate ligand that possesses three bidentate bridging carboxyl groups. In addition, the formate anion is a monodentate ligand in 1 and plays a bidentate bridge in 2. Without a secondary carboxylate ligand, one 2D network [Cd­(bpmb)2] n and two 1D polymers [Zn­(bpmb)2] n ·​nH2O and [Ni(bpmb)2­(H2O)2] n ·​4nH2O have been reported, in which the ratio of metal ions to bpmb is 1:2 due to that the large-sized bpmb ligand has less negative charge (−1 valence). In our two-ligand assembly systems, the ratio of zinc ion to bpmb is 1:1 (1, 2, 3, 6), 3:2 (4), or 2:1 (5). The carboxylate secondary ligands play important roles in supplying a negative charge and promoting structural diversity in constructing these high dimensional porous MOFs.
elements.clean_text: As secondary ligands, the poly(carboxylic acid)s are fully deprotonated except for a partly deprotonated 1,2,4,5-H2btec ligand in 6 (Scheme ). The fumarate and 1,2,4,5-H2btec dianions both act as a bidentate bridge to link Zn(II) ions via two monodentate carboxyl groups. d-Camphorate is a tetradentate ligand to bridge two pairs of Zn(II) ions via two bidentate bridging carboxyl groups. 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylate is a hexadentate ligand that possesses three bidentate bridging carboxyl groups. In addition, the formate anion is a monodentate ligand in 1 and plays a bidentate bridge in 2. Without a secondary carboxylate ligand, one 2D network [Cd(bpmb)2] n   and two 1D polymers [Zn(bpmb)2] n ⋅nH2O and [Ni(bpmb)2(H2O)2] n ⋅4nH2O have been reported, in which the ratio of metal ions to bpmb is 1:2 due to that the large-sized bpmb ligand has less negative charge (-1 valence). In our two-ligand assembly systems, the ratio of zinc ion to bpmb is 1:1 (1, 2, 3, 6), 3:2 (4), or 2:1 (5). The carboxylate secondary ligands play important roles in supplying a negative charge and promoting structural diversity in constructing these high dimensional porous MOFs.

elements.content: Moreover, varied coordination geometries around the Zn(II) centers are observed. Complexes 3 and 6 contain tetrahedral zinc centers, whereas 2 and 4 contain octahedral zinc centers. Complex 1 possesses tetrahedral and octahedral zinc centers, whereas 5 possesses trigonal-bipyramidal and octahedral zinc centers. We notice that all of the 4-coordinate Zn(II) complexes adopt a tetrahedral geometry. To our best knowledge, no planar-square Zn(II) complex was reported. We consider that Zn(II) has a filled d10 orbital, and thus, the dsp2 orbital hybrid is impossible. Therefore, the 4-coordinate Zn(II) center can only adopt an sp3 hybrid that leads to a tetrahedral geometry. Meanwhile, a 6-coordinate octahedral geometry (sp3d2 hybrid) and a 5-coordinate trigonal-bipyramidal geometry (sp3d hybrid) are also common to Zn(II) complexes.
elements.clean_text: Moreover, varied coordination geometries around the Zn(II) centers are observed. Complexes 3 and 6 contain tetrahedral zinc centers, whereas 2 and 4 contain octahedral zinc centers. Complex 1 possesses tetrahedral and octahedral zinc centers, whereas 5 possesses trigonal-bipyramidal and octahedral zinc centers. We notice that all of the 4-coordinate Zn(II) complexes adopt a tetrahedral geometry. To our best knowledge, no planar-square Zn(II) complex was reported. We consider that Zn(II) has a filled d10 orbital, and thus, the dsp2 orbital hybrid is impossible. Therefore, the 4-coordinate Zn(II) center can only adopt an sp3 hybrid that leads to a tetrahedral geometry. Meanwhile, a 6-coordinate octahedral geometry (sp3d2 hybrid) and a 5-coordinate trigonal-bipyramidal geometry (sp3d hybrid) are also common to Zn(II) complexes.

elements.content: The TG–DSC curves of 1–6 were determined in the temperature range of 20–800 °C (Figure S4, ). As shown in Figure , the thermogravimetric curve indicates that complex 1 released four lattice water molecules in the 50–100 °C range with an endothermic peak at 60 °C (found 8.10%, calcd. 7.70%). The anhydrous framework of [Zn­(bpmb)­(HCOO)] n ·[Zn­(bpmb)­(OH)] n is thermally stable up to 219 °C, and then the framework successively decomposes to 800 °C without stopping. Complex 2 is thermally stable under 237 °C and then releases bpmb and formate ligands continuously to afford ZnO residue at 772 °C (found 20.02%, calcd. 18.26%). Complex 3 releases nine lattice water molecules in the 30–82 °C range with an endothermic peak at 78 °C (found 14.49%, calcd. 15.05%). The anhydrous compound is thermally stable until 352 °C. Then the successive weight-loss process corresponds to the decomposition of bpmb and fumarate ligands. Thermogravimetric analysis indicates that the lattice water molecules in 3 are easily released at room temperature. We also observed that the single crystal of 3 is easy to effloresce. Hence, the single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of 3 was carried out at 193(2) K.

elements.content: The thermogravimetric curves of 1 and 3 indicate that both complexes lost all lattice water molecules under 100 °C, and their anhydrous porous frameworks are thermally stable to 219 and 352 °C, respectively. The samples of 1 and 3 for N2 sorption experiments were prepared by heating at 120 °C under vacuum for 7 h to remove all guest water molecules. The N2 adsorption isotherms of 1 and 3 at 77 K are shown in Figure S5a,b (). Complexes 1 and 3 show type-II and type-III adsorption behaviors, respectively. Complex 1 exhibits low N2 uptake at 77 K, and it adsorbs 13.3 cm3 g–1, corresponding to a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of 10.9 cm2 g–1 and a Langmuir surface area of 19.1 cm2 g–1. The pore volume calculated from the maximum N2 adsorption was 0.0182 cm3 g–1. The N2 adsorption isotherm of 3 exhibits high N2 uptake compared to 1 at high pressure. Complex 3 adsorbs 53.6 cm3 g–1, corresponding to a BET surface area of 21.0 cm2 g–1 and a Langmuir surface area of 39.0 cm2 g–1. The pore volume calculated from the maximum N2 adsorption was 0.0789 cm3 g–1.

N2 Adsorption

The thermogravimetric curves of 1 and 3 indicate that both complexes lost all lattice water molecules under 100 °C, and their anhydrous porous frameworks are thermally stable to 219 and 352 °C, respectively. The samples of 1 and 3 for N2 sorption experiments were prepared by heating at 120 °C under vacuum for 7 h to remove all guest water molecules. The N2 adsorption isotherms of 1 and 3 at 77 K are shown in Figure S5a,b (). Complexes 1 and 3 show type-II and type-III adsorption behaviors, respectively. Complex 1 exhibits low N2 uptake at 77 K, and it adsorbs 13.3 cm3 g-1, corresponding to a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 10.9 cm2 g-1 and a Langmuir surface area of 19.1 cm2 g-1. The pore volume calculated from the maximum N2 adsorption was 0.0182 cm3 g-1. The N2 adsorption isotherm of 3 exhibits high N2 uptake compared to 1 at high pressure. Complex 3 adsorbs 53.6 cm3 g-1, corresponding to a BET surface area of 21.0 cm2 g-1 and a Langmuir surface area of 39.0 cm2 g-1. The pore volume calculated from the maximum N2 adsorption was 0.0789 cm3 g-1.

elements.content: It is well-known that d10 transition-metal complexes possess varied luminescence behaviors. Organic ligands and their coordination modes significantly affect the emission wavelength and luminescence mechanism. The luminescence behaviors of Zn(II) complexes 1–6 are investigated. The emission spectra of 1–6 are shown in Figure , and their excitation spectra are shown in Figure S6 (). Upon excitation at 377 nm, the maximum emission peaks are observed at 431 nm for 1, 425 nm for 2, 434 nm for 3, 417 nm for 4, 429 nm for 5, and 460 nm for 6. All the Zn(II) complexes are blue luminescent emitters. Complexes 1 and 5 emit strong luminescence, which are potential blue luminescent materials.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence

It is well-known that d10 transition-metal complexes possess varied luminescence behaviors. Organic ligands and their coordination modes significantly affect the emission wavelength and luminescence mechanism. The luminescence behaviors of Zn(II) complexes 1-6 are investigated. The emission spectra of 1-6 are shown in Figure , and their excitation spectra are shown in Figure S6 (). Upon excitation at 377 nm, the maximum emission peaks are observed at 431 nm for 1, 425 nm for 2, 434 nm for 3, 417 nm for 4, 429 nm for 5, and 460 nm for 6. All the Zn(II) complexes are blue luminescent emitters. Complexes 1 and 5 emit strong luminescence, which are potential blue luminescent materials.

elements.content: Emission spectra of Zn(II) complexes 1–6 in the solid state.
elements.clean_text: 8  Emission spectra of Zn(II) complexes 1-6 in the solid state.

elements.content: To understand the emission mechanism, the emission spectra of free Hbpmb, 1,3,5-H3btc and 1,2,4,5-H4btec aromatic ligands are determined for comparison (Figure S7, ). With similar excitation conditions under 377 nm light, Hbpmb exhibits an emission peak centered at 425 nm. The similar emission energies between Zn(II) complexes 1–5 and the free Hbpmb ligand indicate that their most possible luminescent mechanism originates from the Hbpmb ligand-centered emission. The luminescence of 6 is obviously weak and red-shifted in comparison to that of 1–5 and Hbpmb. Considering that the Zn(II) ion is difficult to oxidize, it is rarely in the nature of metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT). The 1,2,4,5-H4btec secondary ligand has a broad weak emission band near 445 nm. Therefore, the luminescence of 6 can be assigned to 1,2,4,5-H4btec ligand-centered emission.

With similar excitation conditions under 377 nm light, Hbpmb exhibits an emission peak centered at 425 nm. The similar emission energies between Zn(II) complexes 1-5 and the free Hbpmb ligand indicate that their most possible luminescent mechanism originates from the Hbpmb ligand-centered emission. The luminescence of 6 is obviously weak and red-shifted in comparison to that of 1-5 and Hbpmb. Considering that the Zn(II) ion is difficult to oxidize, it is rarely in the nature of metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT). The 1,2,4,5-H4btec secondary ligand has a broad weak emission band near 445 nm. Therefore, the luminescence of 6 can be assigned to 1,2,4,5-H4btec ligand-centered emission.

elements.content: In summary, six novel zinc metal–organic frameworks based on a 3,5-bis(4-pyridyl­methoxy)­benzoate primary ligand and four polycarboxylate secondary ligands have been solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. Complex 1 is constructed of two independent neutral 3D MOFs with large 1D nanosized square channels, which are further entangled by each other to give an unexpected 4-fold [2 + 2] interpenetrating architecture. Complex 2 is an isomer of the 3D [Zn­(bpmb)­(HCOO)] n piece in 1. Complex 3 is a 2D double-layered network that possesses 1D nanosized pores. These 2D double layers are further interlocked with each other to form an interesting 3D polycatenation array. A general solvothermal method is proposed for preparing carboxylate complexes in DMF−H2O solutions without any basic additive. The thermal stabilities of six complexes and the N2 adsorption behaviors of 1 and 3 have been investigated. All the Zn(II) complexes emit blue luminescence. These research results reveal that 3,5-bis(4-pyridyl­methoxy)­benzoate is a valuable large-sized flexible multidentate ligand in constructing porous MOFs. The further study for interpenetration, entanglement, and polycatenation systems is under way.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, six novel zinc metal-organic frameworks based on a 3,5-bis(4-pyridylmethoxy)benzoate primary ligand and four polycarboxylate secondary ligands have been solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. Complex 1 is constructed of two independent neutral 3D MOFs with large 1D nanosized square channels, which are further entangled by each other to give an unexpected 4-fold [2 + 2] interpenetrating architecture. Complex 2 is an isomer of the 3D [Zn(bpmb)(HCOO)] n  piece in 1. Complex 3 is a 2D double-layered network that possesses 1D nanosized pores. These 2D double layers are further interlocked with each other to form an interesting 3D polycatenation array. A general solvothermal method is proposed for preparing carboxylate complexes in DMF-H2O solutions without any basic additive. The thermal stabilities of six complexes and the N2 adsorption behaviors of 1 and 3 have been investigated. All the Zn(II) complexes emit blue luminescence. These research results reveal that 3,5-bis(4-pyridylmethoxy)benzoate is a valuable large-sized flexible multidentate ligand in constructing porous MOFs. The further study for interpenetration, entanglement, and polycatenation systems is under way.

cln_elements.content:
The TG–DSC curves of 1–6 were determined in the temperature range of 20–800 °C (Figure S4, ). As shown in Figure , the thermogravimetric curve indicates that complex 1 released four lattice water molecules in the 50–100 °C range with an endothermic peak at 60 °C (found 8.10%, calcd. 7.70%). The anhydrous framework of [Zn­(bpmb)­(HCOO)] n ·[Zn­(bpmb)­(OH)] n is thermally stable up to 219 °C, and then the framework successively decomposes to 800 °C without stopping. Complex 2 is thermally stable under 237 °C and then releases bpmb and formate ligands continuously to afford ZnO residue at 772 °C (found 20.02%, calcd. 18.26%). Complex 3 releases nine lattice water molecules in the 30–82 °C range with an endothermic peak at 78 °C (found 14.49%, calcd. 15.05%). The anhydrous compound is thermally stable until 352 °C. Then the successive weight-loss process corresponds to the decomposition of bpmb and fumarate ligands. Thermogravimetric analysis indicates that the lattice water molecules in 3 are easily released at room temperature. We also observed that the single crystal of 3 is easy to effloresce. Hence, the single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of 3 was carried out at 193(2) K.

Complex 4 is thermally stable under 358 °C and then releases bpmb and d-camphorate ligands continuously to afford ZnO residue at 750 °C (found 19.91%, calcd. 19.30%). Complex 5 loses one lattice DMA molecule in the 168–219 °C range with an endothermic peak at 200 °C (found 12.20%, calcd 11.50%). The anhydrous framework of [Zn2­(bpmb)­(1,3,5-btc)] n is thermally stable until 423 °C and then releases bpmb and 1,3,5-btc ligands continuously to afford ZnO residue at 600 °C (found 19.12%, calcd. 21.50%). Complex 6 releases four lattice water molecules in the 30–90 °C range with an endothermic peak at 76 °C (found 10.01%, calcd. 9.94%). The anhydrous network remains stable until 268 °C and then successively decomposes to 800 °C without stopping.

N<sub>2</sub> Adsorption

The thermogravimetric curves of 1 and 3 indicate that both complexes lost all lattice water molecules under 100 °C, and their anhydrous porous frameworks are thermally stable to 219 and 352 °C, respectively. The samples of 1 and 3 for N2 sorption experiments were prepared by heating at 120 °C under vacuum for 7 h to remove all guest water molecules. The N2 adsorption isotherms of 1 and 3 at 77 K are shown in Figure S5a,b (). Complexes 1 and 3 show type-II and type-III adsorption behaviors, respectively. Complex 1 exhibits low N2 uptake at 77 K, and it adsorbs 13.3 cm3 g–1, corresponding to a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of 10.9 cm2 g–1 and a Langmuir surface area of 19.1 cm2 g–1. The pore volume calculated from the maximum N2 adsorption was 0.0182 cm3 g–1. The N2 adsorption isotherm of 3 exhibits high N2 uptake compared to 1 at high pressure. Complex 3 adsorbs 53.6 cm3 g–1, corresponding to a BET surface area of 21.0 cm2 g–1 and a Langmuir surface area of 39.0 cm2 g–1. The pore volume calculated from the maximum N2 adsorption was 0.0789 cm3 g–1.

Photoluminescence

It is well-known that d10 transition-metal complexes possess varied luminescence behaviors. Organic ligands and their coordination modes significantly affect the emission wavelength and luminescence mechanism. The luminescence behaviors of Zn(II) complexes 1–6 are investigated. The emission spectra of 1–6 are shown in Figure , and their excitation spectra are shown in Figure S6 (). Upon excitation at 377 nm, the maximum emission peaks are observed at 431 nm for 1, 425 nm for 2, 434 nm for 3, 417 nm for 4, 429 nm for 5, and 460 nm for 6. All the Zn(II) complexes are blue luminescent emitters. Complexes 1 and 5 emit strong luminescence, which are potential blue luminescent materials.
